description.narrative:
Empowerment of female micro-entrepreneurs and home-bound handicraft producers through durable marketing solutions II In the poorer suburbs of Kabul, Jalalabad and Mazar i Sharif thousands of women have relatively good skills in handicrafts such as embroidery, but cannot find markets for their products. Except for work for domestic needs and/or of households in their direct neighbourhood, theonly real outlet option is to do piece work for shopkeepers. That work is hard to find (generally piece work is available for less than 20% of the women who are looking for work), poorly paid and the women are often cheated. Relations between pieceworkers and shopkeepers tend to be strained with neither side able to understand or address the problems of the other. In Afghanistan more than 90%of women are home bound and thus cannot search for market opportunities themselves and lack market information. Zardozi supports these women, who are working from home to develop local markets for their products, through the donor-funded Markets for Afghan Artisans programme. From 2006 to end 2007, Zardozi operated with only minor donor funding. Oxfam Novib (ON) started supporting Zardozi initially in the fall of 2007 with financing a survey in three areas and trades in Afghanistan. On this basis Zardozi chose its intervention modules area and trade for which ON funded a one-year pilot programme for interventions in Jalalabad and Kabul (Jan – Dec 2008).
The pilot project was in 2008 followed up by a programme that was initially planned for a period of three years intervention for‘empowerment of female micro-entrepreneurs’ in Dashte Barchi, an area on the outskirts of Kabul which lacks accurate water and electricity services and is characterised by low-wage labourers and ahigh unemployment rate, that has expanded rapidly over the past five years. Predominantly Hazara people established there, though also many Tajik and Pushtun families are living in the area. The women of the area have traditionally engaged in embroideryto supplement their income. Many NGOs over the years have provided short training programmes to women in tailoring and embroidery, but unfortunately they stayed too short and focused too much on only skills tomake it sustainable. Zardozi managed to adopta model which allows homebound producers to access markets through female commission agents (sale agents). Motivated and relatively mobile women living in the poorest suburbs are identified as sales agents. These sales agents are trained by the projectstaff in marketing, product development/design, quality assurance, pricing, etc.; each sale agentmust work together with at least 20 poor home producers to whom they provide services related to the skills they have been trained on. The home producers further receive skills training from the project as necessary, for instance on tailoring, beading and other embellishment items.
The Zardozi programme has over time expanded from Kabul to Jalalabad and Mazar and already covers approximately2,500 women. Zardozi has currently offices and projects in Kabul and Jalalabad including a small project office in Dashte Barchi. Zardozi also has an office in Peshawar. With the view on Zardozi’s wishes to expand the intervention towards other regions, With the approvalof the new three year programme the earlier agreement between Oxfam Novib and Zardozi (A- 268-2; extending till December 2011) will make place for the new multi-donor consortium agreement.
The desired long-term impact of the currently proposed fundingof interventions (by DFID, SIDA and ON), is to reduce poverty in the target provinces (Kabul, Nangarhar, Balkh and Herat) .
In the medium-term it is expected income for female home producers and entrepreneurs will be increased (by 100% to 300%) byenabling them to develop and market competitive products through strong industry association.
This medium term objective is based on the experience from the first three years of the Zardozi programme, while also regional research from other, similar programmes supports such result.
The outputs that are expected from supporting the expansion of the programme are that 236 shopkeepers, 400 new female sale agents and 4,200 new home workers will gain improved capacity to produce market-led products. In total, the proposed expansion programme will positively impact directly 9,120 women. With an average household size of 8 people, this means some additional 64,000 people will indirectly benefit from the project. New female sale agents and home workers' business skills will be increased through training; increased market opportunities for female sale agents and home workers will be facilitated through linkages to sales channels and the development of improved marketing capacity; and, a functional and sustainable support association will be capable of providing market facilitation and business support services to its members.
Problems to be resolved: Low Profit Margins and Constraints on Asset Accumulation Low Business Capacity Home-based Production Systems Product Design and Quality Problems Limited Access to Retail Opportunities
Which implies attention to the following intervention domains: (1) Product Development (2) Business Development (3) Marketing and (4) Association Development.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam works to help poor and marginalized people to gain control over their own lives by exercising their right to political participation, freedom of expression and information, freedom of assembly, and access to justice. Many projects currently being executed by Oxfam in Afghanistan on women and youth fall under this campaign.
In Afghanistan, ON has been working with local NGOs, civil society organisations and networks through a number of initiatives to raise awareness about human rights, promote women's participation and leadership, and empower citizens to speak out on issues that affect their lives and to improve governance

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
